JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 15.

DR. REMSEN RESIGNS PRESIDENCY
Administration of University Is in Hands
of Faculty Committee, With Dr.
Welch as Chairman.

At the last meeting of the trustees of the University, held last
Monday, the administration of the
University was put into the hands
of a committee of the faculty.
This action was taken by the trustees as a result of the resignation
of Dr. Remsen as acting president.
The committee form of administration is not an experiment, as it has
been used in other interregna. Dr.
William H. Welch Was appointed
chairman of the committee, which
IS composed of the following members of the faculty:
Prof. Basil L. Gildersleeve, Prof.
Joseph S. Ames, Prof. William B.
Clark, Prof. William H. Howell,
Prof. Westel W. Willoughby, and
Dean Edward H. Griffin.
It will be remembered that last
June Dr. Remsen asked to be relieved of his executive duties, but
the Board of Trustees persuaded
him to remain as president of the
University Until his successor could
be chosen. Dr. Remsen consented
to do so, and directed the affairs
of the University until the first of
January, when he went to the Hopkins Hospital for a slight operation.
He was back at the University for
a few hours last week, but did not
settle down to take up his usual
duties, as his doctors had ordered
him to take a vacation, in order that
he might fully recuperate. Dr.
Remsen has prepared, therefore, to
take a month's vacation at Camden,
S. C., for which place he leaves
Tuesday. -In order that the University might not suffer from his continued absence, Dr. Remsen felt
called on to resign before going
South.
It is understood -that a new president will not be decided upon in
time for inaugtiration during this
academic year. The Board oft'Trustees had under consideration a long
list of names, which at one time
numbered over a hundred. The list
has been greatly shortened, there
being now less than twenty men
under consideration.

CORRECTION
In the last issue of THE NEws-

LETTER it was stated that the an-

nual Maryland Peace Contest in
oratory would be held April 7.
This is a mistake. The contest will
take place on the night of Friday,
April 4. Harry W. Richmond has
been appointed chairman of a committee of the Grotius Society to
make the arrangements.

Engineering Society.

The fourth regular meetincr of the
Johns Hopkins Engineering6Society
was held in the physics lecture-room
last Monday, January 27, at I
P. M. The speaker was Mr. A. S.
Loizeaux, electrical engineer for the
Consolidated Gas Company of this
city. His subject was "A Symposium of Recent Problems in Central Station Engineering." He discussed some of the difficulties undergone in the construction of the dam
at McCall's Ferry, and other works
in and around Baltimore.

Record-Breaking Collection.

Seven million dollars was collected in less than two hours at a
meeting in New York on January
17 of alumni of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology for building the new "Tech" in Boston.
President R. C. Maclaurin has
broken all records for college presidents in the gathering of such a
large sum in so small a time. There
were 1,000 alumni present, but less
than 500 made the contribution.
One anonymous benefactor gave
82,500,000.
At a celebration meeting, Dr.
Maclaurin said in part:
"The star of 'Tech' is in the
ascendant; at least she is coming
into her own, and the hearts of all
that love her are stirred by the possibilities of her future glories.
"For months I have been bombarded by the eager questions from
alumni and others: 'When will
building begin?' T regret the apparent indecision, but if we cannot yet say quite definitely when we
shall begin, I think we can say with
some certainty that we shall end in
the fall of 1915. When I say 'end'
I mean the buildings for which fundamental provision has already been
made through the generosity of Mr.
'Smith,' namely the strictly educational buildings, lecture-rooms, laboratories, etc."

Coming Lecture.

Dr. Miller Sails for Europe.

Rev. Dr. Walter Rauchenbusch,
professor of church history in the
Rochester Theological Seminary,
author of "Christianity and the Social Crisis," "The Christianizing of
the Social Order," etc., will lecture
in McCoy Hall, under the auspices
of the Young Women's Christian
Association, on Monday, February
io, at 8 P. M. His subject will be
"Christian Social Service."

Among the passengers of the
"Prinz Friedrich Wilhelm," which
sailed for Europe from New York,
last Thursday, January 30, was Dr.
C. W. E. Miller, associate professor of Greek in this University.
He took his wife and two daughters
over to Europe with him last summer, and they are still there, and
will meet him at his arrival on the
other side. His son, who has a position in an office in this city, will
remain here. It is Dr. Miller's intention to visit Greece, if it is at all
practicable to do so, in order to
carry on various lines of work that
he has on hand at present. He alp
intends to visit the famous libraries
of the Continent, in order to get
hold of manuscripts which are necessary for his studies. During his
absence, Dr., Spieker will conduct
his undergraduate classes. Dr.
Miller expects to return to Baltimore about the first week in September, and will resume his work
here at the beginning of the next
scholastic year.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 3, 1913
Honoring An Alumnus.

It is no more than natural that
a university should feel proud of
an alumnus who has been honored
with the highest office in the gift
of the American people. Hopkins
is perfectly justified in doing everything in her power to let Woodrow
Wilson perceive the pride she takes
in him. It is to be hoped that it
was with this end in view that the
managers of the Fifth RegimentHopkins indoor games invited the
President-elect to referee the contests, but it must be said, flatly and
bluntly, that their action is open
to criticism.
Nothing is an honor which does
not in some way add to the recipient a dignity which he did not possess before. It is perfectly plain
that to referee the Fifth RegimentHopkins contests could add nothing to Governor Wilson's dignity;
it would be the games, therefore,
and not the President-elect, who
would be honored. Perhaps the
managers of the meet did not look
at the matter in this light; it is to
be trusted that they did not, for in
it their action does not appear to
advantage. The fact that their invitation was such as to confer honor,
not on ,Governor Wilson but on the
games, subjects that invitation to
interpretation as an attempt to advertise the games through Governor
Wilson; and no tendency of the day
is more to be regretted than the
using of the names of men in public life for advertising purposes.
It is not to be supposed that the
managers of the meet, in sending
the invitation, had any such design,
but it is unfortunate that they took
a step capable of such interpretation.
In 1902 Hopkins conferred on
Woodrow Wilson, then president of
Princeton, the degree of doctor of

laws, the highest academic honor
within her gift. Since that time
other honors have come upon him,
which truly demand recognition
from his alma mater; but there is
only one adequate way in which
we can give that recognition. That
way is for the University, individually and collectively, to support his
efforts to safeguard the welfare of
the American people; to incorporate
into its principles and into its life
the great ideals of law, liberty and
democracy, for which he is striving,
and that surpassing hatred of special privilege which has characterized his whole political career. The
best way for Hopkins to honor
Woodrow Wilson is to support his
principles; the next best way is to
admire him as the exponent of
those principles; and it is to be
hoped that it was this admiration
rather than any commercial motive
that led the managers of the -Fifth
Regiment-Hopkins games to extend
him their unfortunate invitation.

MEYER & THALHEIMER

Max S. Rohde, Football Coach.

Max Spencer Rohde, former star
tackle of the University of Chicago
eleven, and whose playing with the
Johns Hopkins eleven two seasons
ago won for him the almost unanimous choice of pickers of all-Maryland teams as guard, was selected
yesterday to coach the Hopkins
eleven during the 1913 season.
The football advisers — Horace
Burroughs and Dr. Harvey Stone—
decided upon Rohde after considering a number of applicants, many
of whom 'were former Hopkins
men, at a preliminary meeting, and
when his name was presented to
the Athletic Board yesterday at five
o'clock it received ratification at
once. The meeting, which was executive, lasted about an hour, which
is comparatively short for such
meetings.
Rohde is in New York, and although he has not formally accepted
the position, there is no doubt that
he will, because he wants to do some
post-graduate work at the University.
The new coach graduated from
Chicago in• 19o8. He had played
at tackle for two years and was
picked as a star player by many
Western papers and experts. He
came to the Hopkins Medical
School, but was not on the local
eleven until season before last. Although he had not played for three
years, it did not take long to get
in trim, and his work was of the
first order. He was right guard,
playing centre when Hopkins was
on defensive. Rohde is 26 years
old and lives at Princeton, Ill.
The selection came as a surprise
to many followers of Hopkins football. While Rohde always was a
popular player, he did not. come
into contact with undergraduate
life at Hopkins, and the general
football following did not get to
know him well. As a player he was
quiet, steady and could always be
relied upon to make a hole in the.
opposing line.

THE NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY
THE MARYLAND PEACE SOCIETY
Senator Burton Speaks on the Canal
Question—Interesting Meetif,g Held.
Officers Elected for Next Year.

The Maryland Peace Society held
its fourth annual meeting in McCoy
Hall last Tuesday evening. Mr.
Eugene Levering, who has been acting as president of the Society since
Mr. Theodore Marburg left for
Belgium, presided at the meeting.
The principal speaker was United
States Senator Theodore E. Burton,
of Ohio, who is the president of the
.American Peace Society. The announcement that he would speak
brought out a very large and attentive audience. He spoke upon a
two-fold subject.:
I. "Arbitration as An Influence
for Peace," and
2. "The Panama Canal Controversy."
After a dissertation upon the first
part of his subject, Senator Burton
turned to the question which will
probably be of interest to the members of the junior and senior classes.
These classes are to engage in a debate in March, upon the Canal
question, and Senator Burton has
brought out some facts that ought
to prove of value to both classes.
He spoke for the Canal toll, and
stated that it is not the legislators,
nor even the coast-wise shipping

interests, that are in favor of exemption from toll, but only a few Pacific
Coast concerns which are desirous
of getting their produce to the Atlantic Coast more cheaply than they
could otherwise.
Rev. Dr. Thomas H. Lewis, president of Western Maryland College,
and president of the Maryland
Branch of the American School
Peace League, delivered a short,
but witty address on "The School
Teacher as the Advance Agent of
Peace." Dr. B. F. Trueblood, secretary of the American Peace Society, gave a short discussion of the
Balkan situation. Mr. George R.
Gaither read the list of nominations
for the ensuing year. The election
was made as follows:
President—Theodore Marburg.
Acting President—Eugene Levering.
Secretary—Dr. Andrew B. Wood.
Treasurer—Equitable Mortgage
and Trust Company.
Vice-Presidents—Governor Goldsborough, Cardinal Gibbons, Dr. Ira
Remsen, Dr. William H. Welch,
Mrs. B. Cotten, R. Brent Keyser,
J. Barry Mahool, Bishop John G.
Murray, Dean Edward H. Griffin,
Mrs. William M. Ellicott, Miss E.
L. Lord, Mrs. B. W. Corkran, Dr.
John F. Goucher, Mrs. William J.
Brown, Rev. Oliver Huckel and
Henry F. Baker.

Schedule Practically Completed—Prospects Are Bright for a Strong Nine.
Scrub Team to Organize.

Baseball was officially launched as
one of the major spring sports at
the annual organization meeting,
held last Thursday afternoon in the
Trophy Room of the gymnasium.
The meeting was very well attended.
and judging from the number of
new candidates in addition to the
veterans of last year who are back
at the University, the nine should
be an exceptionally strong one.
Much enthusiasm was manifested
at the organization meeting. Captain Ernest J. Pieper presided and
opened the meeting with a short
address in which he emphasized the
fact that the personnel of the team
would not be certain until the 'season actually opened, and that one
candidate had just as good chance
of making the team as another, provided he showed that he could deliver the goods in practice.
Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr., was
present at the meeting, and made a
very fine speech. He told of the
cheering effects in after life of the
remembrance of some particularly
brilliant play during one's college
days. He also advised all present
at the meeting to use their heads
to help correct their deficiencies, and
said that in this way they would be
far more likely to make a position
on the team; if not the first year,
then after several years of trying,
they would be sure to be rewarded.
Coach Eddie Hooper gave a
snappy little 'talk. He told the prospective candidates what would be
expected of them, and he laid down
the requisites for the development
of a first class team.
The complete schedule was announced by Manager C. Leland
Getz:
Saturday, March 22—Rock Hill
College at Homewood.
Tuesday, March 25—University
of Pennsylvania at Homewood.
Wednesday, March 26—University of Virginia at Charlottesville.
Saturday, March 29—Washington College at Homewood.
Saturday, April 19 — Maryland
Agricultural College at Homewood.
Saturday, April 26 — Dickinson
College at Carlisle, Pa.
Saturday, May 3—Delaware College at Newark, Del.
Saturday, May,To—Navy at Annapolis.
Saturday, May 17—St. John's at
Homewood.
Several other games are pending
and may be added to the above list.
A number of good offers for games
were received for the dates just before Easter, and a game had Almost
been arranged with Lehigh, when
negotiations had to be broken off,
as the Homewood grounds committee refused to sanction any home
games before Easter, because of the
uncertainty of the weather conditions.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS' CONCERT

CONTEST!

CONTEST!

"The Glee Club Singer"
For Further Details See Article in Column 4 of This Page

FAVORS A PUBLICITY COMMITTEE
A Chicago Correspondent Discourses on
Vexatious Subject—Thinks the Work
Being Done Is Highly Inefficient.

CHICAGO, January 28, 1913.
MR. JOHN SHARP DICKINSON,
Editor THE NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University.
Dear Sir—The practical value of
the question recently raised of making- the University more widely
known has been repeatedly forced
home to me since I have been out
here in the Middle West, where, to
nine out of ten people, Johns Hopkins means "medial school."
This condition is, I think, largely
due to the wider publicity given in
the past to the Hospital. I am a
careful reader of three Chicago
newspapers, and I can vouch that
the stories about the new technical
school (lid not average "two sticks,"
about five inches. On the other
hand, not a week goes by that there
is not some item from the Hospital.
If the patient who has gone under
the knife is picturesque or popular,
the item often runs half a column.
We all appreciate the work done
at the Medical School, but we know
that this is but a part of the University's achievements. The publicity that has been given that important department is but a promise
of what can be done for the rest
of the University.
From a practical standpoint, the
work being done for the University is highly inefficient. There is
a well known formula used by advertising men to test the probable
value of publicity. It is: Circulation
multiplied . by hiving powcr and
divided by cost. Apply this formula to the Hopkins alumni teaching in another institution. What is
his "circulation"?—only those persons with whom he comes in contact, or who may know of him by
reputation. What is the "buying
power" of those persons ?—only so
many who plan postgraduate work
or who have sons going to college,
qualified always by the financial
ability to conic to Baltimore. What
is the "cost"?—possibly it is nothing, but the cost is the least important factor in the equation, "for any
rate is too high if the circulation and

buying power are not there." It is
plain that the circulation is small
and the buying power very limited.
Moreover, most teaching alumni
took their baccalaureate degree at
other colleges, and their affections
cling to their college rather than
their University. Scholastically, they
are Hopkins men; sentimentally,
they are not. We all know of members of the faculty whose Ph.D. or
M.D. was won at Johns Hopkins,
who have sent their boys back to
their own college.
Now, apply the same formula to
the "University Circular." By these
coldblooded tests the two forms of
publicity mainly relied on by the
faculty, according to Dr. Buchner,
show up as pretty poor "result getcrs."
One would be silly to try to discredit the value of any successful
alumni to the University. The importance of good will and of reputation are appreciated by everyone.
Nobody can doubt but that the
"University Circular" is a necessary, proper publication, well filling
its purpose. But publicity for the
University is, in its last analysis,
a straightforward business proposition. It can be effectively accomplished in a dignified way by other
means than through our own alumni
and the University publications.
Could not a Publicity Committee
be formed to do this very important
work? It might well be composed of
a trustee of the University, a member of the faculty, the registrar, the
editor of the new alumni paper, the
editor of THE NEWS-LETTER and a
couple of alumni, preferably men
living in or near Baltimore. Such
a committee should be headquarters
for Hopkins news, and they should
use every proper and dignified
means to bring the University to
the wider attention of the country.
A great deal could be accomplished
at very little expense. I can promise
that committee one willing helper
out in Chicago.
This is a long letter, but I hope
my great love for Johns Hopkins
and my experience in the advertising and publishing fields may be
sufficient excuse.
Very sincerely yours,

WILLIAMS HAYNES.

Glee and Instrumental Clubs Showing
Up Well in the Rehearsals—Dance
to Follow the Concert.

Too much cannot be said in praise
of the fine showing that both the
Glee and Instrumental Clubs have
made in the rehearsals last week in
preparation for the annual concert
of the combined Musical Clubs to
be given on Tuesday night, February ii, in McCoy Hall. Without the slightest exaggeration, it
can be stated that the Musical Clubs
are in better shape than ever before
in the history of the University.
As has been the custom for the
past two years, a short dance will
follow the concert. This will add
much to the evening's entertainment, especially for the younger
persons in the audience. The list
of patronesses which will be announced in the latter part of this
week is a very fashionable one.
Unique posters have been issued
for the concert, but the management greatly fears that the design
has proven almost too attractive,
and that instead of placing them in
the store windows, where they
would do the most good, many of
the students have appropriated
posters for the purpose of decorating their walls at home. To supply
the need for wall decorations the
management has had a limited number of copies of the "Glee Club
Singer" printed on heavy white
cardboard, without any advertising,
and these can be obtained for the
small sum of five cents apiece, as
long as they hold out. Ben Tappan, who drew the famous "Glee
Club Singer," was clever enough
to somewhat disguise the features
of the member of the Hopkins Glee
Club that he had in mind while
making the drawing. There is quite
a difference of opinion as to which
member of the Club the drawing
most resembles. A free copy of
the drawing, suitable for framing,
will be presented to the reader of
THE NEWS-LETTER making the most
plausible suggestion as to the member of the Club the drawing is
really intended to represent.

write out the name of the original
of the drawing and give the reasons for your choice in not more
than twenty-five words. Mail the
same to the Contest Editor of THE
NEWS-LETTER, who has been placed
in charge of the matter by the manager of the Musical Clubs.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 15.

DR. REMSEN RESIGNS PRESIDENCY
Administration of University Is in Hands
of Faculty Committee, With Dr.
Welch as Chairman.

At the last meeting of the trustees of the University, held last
Monday, the administration of the
University was put into the hands
of a committee of the faculty.
This action was taken by the trustees as a result of the resignation
of Dr. Remsen as acting president.
The committee form of administration is not an experiment, as it has
been used in other interregna. Dr.
William H. Welch Was appointed
chairman of the committee, which
IS composed of the following members of the faculty:
Prof. Basil L. Gildersleeve, Prof.
Joseph S. Ames, Prof. William B.
Clark, Prof. William H. Howell,
Prof. Westel W. Willoughby, and
Dean Edward H. Griffin.
It will be remembered that last
June Dr. Remsen asked to be relieved of his executive duties, but
the Board of Trustees persuaded
him to remain as president of the
University Until his successor could
be chosen. Dr. Remsen consented
to do so, and directed the affairs
of the University until the first of
January, when he went to the Hopkins Hospital for a slight operation.
He was back at the University for
a few hours last week, but did not
settle down to take up his usual
duties, as his doctors had ordered
him to take a vacation, in order that
he might fully recuperate. Dr.
Remsen has prepared, therefore, to
take a month's vacation at Camden,
S. C., for which place he leaves
Tuesday. -In order that the University might not suffer from his continued absence, Dr. Remsen felt
called on to resign before going
South.
It is understood -that a new president will not be decided upon in
time for inaugtiration during this
academic year. The Board oft'Trustees had under consideration a long
list of names, which at one time
numbered over a hundred. The list
has been greatly shortened, there
being now less than twenty men
under consideration.

In the last issue of THE NEws-

LETTER it was stated that the an-

nual Maryland Peace Contest in
oratory would be held April 7.
This is a mistake. The contest will
take place on the night of Friday,
April 4. Harry W. Richmond has
been appointed chairman of a committee of the Grotius Society to
make the arrangements.

The fourth regular meetincr of the
Johns Hopkins Engineering6Society
was held in the physics lecture-room
last Monday, January 27, at I
P. M. The speaker was Mr. A. S.
Loizeaux, electrical engineer for the
Consolidated Gas Company of this
city. His subject was "A Symposium of Recent Problems in Central Station Engineering." He discussed some of the difficulties undergone in the construction of the dam
at McCall's Ferry, and other works
in and around Baltimore.

Record-Breaking Collection.

Seven million dollars was collected in less than two hours at a
meeting in New York on January
17 of alumni of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology for building the new "Tech" in Boston.
President R. C. Maclaurin has
broken all records for college presidents in the gathering of such a
large sum in so small a time. There
were 1,000 alumni present, but less
than 500 made the contribution.
One anonymous benefactor gave
82,500,000.
At a celebration meeting, Dr.
Maclaurin said in part:
"The star of 'Tech' is in the
ascendant; at least she is coming
into her own, and the hearts of all
that love her are stirred by the possibilities of her future glories.
"For months I have been bombarded by the eager questions from
alumni and others: 'When will
building begin?' T regret the apparent indecision, but if we cannot yet say quite definitely when we
shall begin, I think we can say with
some certainty that we shall end in
the fall of 1915. When I say 'end'
I mean the buildings for which fundamental provision has already been
made through the generosity of Mr.
'Smith,' namely the strictly educational buildings, lecture-rooms, laboratories, etc."

Coming Lecture.

Dr. Miller Sails for Europe.

Rev. Dr. Walter Rauchenbusch,
professor of church history in the
Rochester Theological Seminary,
author of "Christianity and the Social Crisis," "The Christianizing of
the Social Order," etc., will lecture
in McCoy Hall, under the auspices
of the Young Women's Christian
Association, on Monday, February
io, at 8 P. M. His subject will be
"Christian Social Service."

Among the passengers of the
"Prinz Friedrich Wilhelm," which
sailed for Europe from New York,
last Thursday, January 30, was Dr.
C. W. E. Miller, associate professor of Greek in this University.
He took his wife and two daughters
over to Europe with him last summer, and they are still there, and
will meet him at his arrival on the
other side. His son, who has a position in an office in this city, will
remain here. It is Dr. Miller's intention to visit Greece, if it is at all
practicable to do so, in order to
carry on various lines of work that
he has on hand at present. He alp
intends to visit the famous libraries
of the Continent, in order to get
hold of manuscripts which are necessary for his studies. During his
absence, Dr., Spieker will conduct
his undergraduate classes. Dr.
Miller expects to return to Baltimore about the first week in September, and will resume his work
here at the beginning of the next
scholastic year.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 3, 1913
Honoring An Alumnus.

It is no more than natural that
a university should feel proud of
an alumnus who has been honored
with the highest office in the gift
of the American people. Hopkins
is perfectly justified in doing everything in her power to let Woodrow
Wilson perceive the pride she takes
in him. It is to be hoped that it
was with this end in view that the
managers of the Fifth RegimentHopkins indoor games invited the
President-elect to referee the contests, but it must be said, flatly and
bluntly, that their action is open
to criticism.
Nothing is an honor which does
not in some way add to the recipient a dignity which he did not possess before. It is perfectly plain
that to referee the Fifth RegimentHopkins contests could add nothing to Governor Wilson's dignity;
it would be the games, therefore,
and not the President-elect, who
would be honored. Perhaps the
managers of the meet did not look
at the matter in this light; it is to
be trusted that they did not, for in
it their action does not appear to
advantage. The fact that their invitation was such as to confer honor,
not on ,Governor Wilson but on the
games, subjects that invitation to
interpretation as an attempt to advertise the games through Governor
Wilson; and no tendency of the day
is more to be regretted than the
using of the names of men in public life for advertising purposes.
It is not to be supposed that the
managers of the meet, in sending
the invitation, had any such design,
but it is unfortunate that they took
a step capable of such interpretation.
In 1902 Hopkins conferred on
Woodrow Wilson, then president of
Princeton, the degree of doctor of

laws, the highest academic honor
within her gift. Since that time
other honors have come upon him,
which truly demand recognition
from his alma mater; but there is
only one adequate way in which
we can give that recognition. That
way is for the University, individually and collectively, to support his
efforts to safeguard the welfare of
the American people; to incorporate
into its principles and into its life
the great ideals of law, liberty and
democracy, for which he is striving,
and that surpassing hatred of special privilege which has characterized his whole political career. The
best way for Hopkins to honor
Woodrow Wilson is to support his
principles; the next best way is to
admire him as the exponent of
those principles; and it is to be
hoped that it was this admiration
rather than any commercial motive
that led the managers of the -Fifth
Regiment-Hopkins games to extend
him their unfortunate invitation.

Max S. Rohde, Football Coach.

Max Spencer Rohde, former star
tackle of the University of Chicago
eleven, and whose playing with the
Johns Hopkins eleven two seasons
ago won for him the almost unanimous choice of pickers of all-Maryland teams as guard, was selected
yesterday to coach the Hopkins
eleven during the 1913 season.
The football advisers — Horace
Burroughs and Dr. Harvey Stone—
decided upon Rohde after considering a number of applicants, many
of whom 'were former Hopkins
men, at a preliminary meeting, and
when his name was presented to
the Athletic Board yesterday at five
o'clock it received ratification at
once. The meeting, which was executive, lasted about an hour, which
is comparatively short for such
meetings.
Rohde is in New York, and although he has not formally accepted
the position, there is no doubt that
he will, because he wants to do some
post-graduate work at the University.
The new coach graduated from
Chicago in• 19o8. He had played
at tackle for two years and was
picked as a star player by many
Western papers and experts. He
came to the Hopkins Medical
School, but was not on the local
eleven until season before last. Although he had not played for three
years, it did not take long to get
in trim, and his work was of the
first order. He was right guard,
playing centre when Hopkins was
on defensive. Rohde is 26 years
old and lives at Princeton, Ill.
The selection came as a surprise
to many followers of Hopkins football. While Rohde always was a
popular player, he did not. come
into contact with undergraduate
life at Hopkins, and the general
football following did not get to
know him well. As a player he was
quiet, steady and could always be
relied upon to make a hole in the.
opposing line.

THE NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY
THE MARYLAND PEACE SOCIETY
Senator Burton Speaks on the Canal
Question—Interesting Meetif,g Held.
Officers Elected for Next Year.

The Maryland Peace Society held
its fourth annual meeting in McCoy
Hall last Tuesday evening. Mr.
Eugene Levering, who has been acting as president of the Society since
Mr. Theodore Marburg left for
Belgium, presided at the meeting.
The principal speaker was United
States Senator Theodore E. Burton,
of Ohio, who is the president of the
.American Peace Society. The announcement that he would speak
brought out a very large and attentive audience. He spoke upon a
two-fold subject.:
I. "Arbitration as An Influence
for Peace," and
2. "The Panama Canal Controversy."
After a dissertation upon the first
part of his subject, Senator Burton
turned to the question which will
probably be of interest to the members of the junior and senior classes.
These classes are to engage in a debate in March, upon the Canal
question, and Senator Burton has
brought out some facts that ought
to prove of value to both classes.
He spoke for the Canal toll, and
stated that it is not the legislators,
nor even the coast-wise shipping

interests, that are in favor of exemption from toll, but only a few Pacific
Coast concerns which are desirous
of getting their produce to the Atlantic Coast more cheaply than they
could otherwise.
Rev. Dr. Thomas H. Lewis, president of Western Maryland College,
and president of the Maryland
Branch of the American School
Peace League, delivered a short,
but witty address on "The School
Teacher as the Advance Agent of
Peace." Dr. B. F. Trueblood, secretary of the American Peace Society, gave a short discussion of the
Balkan situation. Mr. George R.
Gaither read the list of nominations
for the ensuing year. The election
was made as follows:
President—Theodore Marburg.
Acting President—Eugene Levering.
Secretary—Dr. Andrew B. Wood.
Treasurer—Equitable Mortgage
and Trust Company.
Vice-Presidents—Governor Goldsborough, Cardinal Gibbons, Dr. Ira
Remsen, Dr. William H. Welch,
Mrs. B. Cotten, R. Brent Keyser,
J. Barry Mahool, Bishop John G.
Murray, Dean Edward H. Griffin,
Mrs. William M. Ellicott, Miss E.
L. Lord, Mrs. B. W. Corkran, Dr.
John F. Goucher, Mrs. William J.
Brown, Rev. Oliver Huckel and
Henry F. Baker.

Schedule Practically Completed—Prospects Are Bright for a Strong Nine.
Scrub Team to Organize.

Baseball was officially launched as
one of the major spring sports at
the annual organization meeting,
held last Thursday afternoon in the
Trophy Room of the gymnasium.
The meeting was very well attended.
and judging from the number of
new candidates in addition to the
veterans of last year who are back
at the University, the nine should
be an exceptionally strong one.
Much enthusiasm was manifested
at the organization meeting. Captain Ernest J. Pieper presided and
opened the meeting with a short
address in which he emphasized the
fact that the personnel of the team
would not be certain until the 'season actually opened, and that one
candidate had just as good chance
of making the team as another, provided he showed that he could deliver the goods in practice.
Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr., was
present at the meeting, and made a
very fine speech. He told of the
cheering effects in after life of the
remembrance of some particularly
brilliant play during one's college
days. He also advised all present
at the meeting to use their heads
to help correct their deficiencies, and
said that in this way they would be
far more likely to make a position
on the team; if not the first year,
then after several years of trying,
they would be sure to be rewarded.
Coach Eddie Hooper gave a
snappy little 'talk. He told the prospective candidates what would be
expected of them, and he laid down
the requisites for the development
of a first class team.
The complete schedule was announced by Manager C. Leland
Getz:
Saturday, March 22—Rock Hill
College at Homewood.
Tuesday, March 25—University
of Pennsylvania at Homewood.
Wednesday, March 26—University of Virginia at Charlottesville.
Saturday, March 29—Washington College at Homewood.
Saturday, April 19 — Maryland
Agricultural College at Homewood.
Saturday, April 26 — Dickinson
College at Carlisle, Pa.
Saturday, May 3—Delaware College at Newark, Del.
Saturday, May,To—Navy at Annapolis.
Saturday, May 17—St. John's at
Homewood.
Several other games are pending
and may be added to the above list.
A number of good offers for games
were received for the dates just before Easter, and a game had Almost
been arranged with Lehigh, when
negotiations had to be broken off,
as the Homewood grounds committee refused to sanction any home
games before Easter, because of the
uncertainty of the weather conditions.

FAVORS A PUBLICITY COMMITTEE
A Chicago Correspondent Discourses on
Vexatious Subject—Thinks the Work
Being Done Is Highly Inefficient.

CHICAGO, January 28, 1913.
MR. JOHN SHARP DICKINSON,
Editor THE NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University.
Dear Sir—The practical value of
the question recently raised of making- the University more widely
known has been repeatedly forced
home to me since I have been out
here in the Middle West, where, to
nine out of ten people, Johns Hopkins means "medial school."
This condition is, I think, largely
due to the wider publicity given in
the past to the Hospital. I am a
careful reader of three Chicago
newspapers, and I can vouch that
the stories about the new technical
school (lid not average "two sticks,"
about five inches. On the other
hand, not a week goes by that there
is not some item from the Hospital.
If the patient who has gone under
the knife is picturesque or popular,
the item often runs half a column.
We all appreciate the work done
at the Medical School, but we know
that this is but a part of the University's achievements. The publicity that has been given that important department is but a promise
of what can be done for the rest
of the University.
From a practical standpoint, the
work being done for the University is highly inefficient. There is
a well known formula used by advertising men to test the probable
value of publicity. It is: Circulation
multiplied . by hiving powcr and
divided by cost. Apply this formula to the Hopkins alumni teaching in another institution. What is
his "circulation"?—only those persons with whom he comes in contact, or who may know of him by
reputation. What is the "buying
power" of those persons ?—only so
many who plan postgraduate work
or who have sons going to college,
qualified always by the financial
ability to conic to Baltimore. What
is the "cost"?—possibly it is nothing, but the cost is the least important factor in the equation, "for any
rate is too high if the circulation and

buying power are not there." It is
plain that the circulation is small
and the buying power very limited.
Moreover, most teaching alumni
took their baccalaureate degree at
other colleges, and their affections
cling to their college rather than
their University. Scholastically, they
are Hopkins men; sentimentally,
they are not. We all know of members of the faculty whose Ph.D. or
M.D. was won at Johns Hopkins,
who have sent their boys back to
their own college.
Now, apply the same formula to
the "University Circular." By these
coldblooded tests the two forms of
publicity mainly relied on by the
faculty, according to Dr. Buchner,
show up as pretty poor "result getcrs."
One would be silly to try to discredit the value of any successful
alumni to the University. The importance of good will and of reputation are appreciated by everyone.
Nobody can doubt but that the
"University Circular" is a necessary, proper publication, well filling
its purpose. But publicity for the
University is, in its last analysis,
a straightforward business proposition. It can be effectively accomplished in a dignified way by other
means than through our own alumni
and the University publications.
Could not a Publicity Committee
be formed to do this very important
work? It might well be composed of
a trustee of the University, a member of the faculty, the registrar, the
editor of the new alumni paper, the
editor of THE NEWS-LETTER and a
couple of alumni, preferably men
living in or near Baltimore. Such
a committee should be headquarters
for Hopkins news, and they should
use every proper and dignified
means to bring the University to
the wider attention of the country.
A great deal could be accomplished
at very little expense. I can promise
that committee one willing helper
out in Chicago.
This is a long letter, but I hope

Glee and Instrumental Clubs Showing
Up Well in the Rehearsals—Dance
to Follow the Concert.

Too much cannot be said in praise
of the fine showing that both the
Glee and Instrumental Clubs have
made in the rehearsals last week in
preparation for the annual concert
of the combined Musical Clubs to
be given on Tuesday night, February ii, in McCoy Hall. Without the slightest exaggeration, it
can be stated that the Musical Clubs
are in better shape than ever before
in the history of the University.
As has been the custom for the
past two years, a short dance will
follow the concert. This will add
much to the evening's entertainment, especially for the younger
persons in the audience. The list
of patronesses which will be announced in the latter part of this
week is a very fashionable one.
Unique posters have been issued
for the concert, but the management greatly fears that the design
has proven almost too attractive,
and that instead of placing them in
the store windows, where they
would do the most good, many of
the students have appropriated
posters for the purpose of decorating their walls at home. To supply
the need for wall decorations the
management has had a limited number of copies of the "Glee Club
Singer" printed on heavy white
cardboard, without any advertising,
and these can be obtained for the
small sum of five cents apiece, as
long as they hold out. Ben Tappan, who drew the famous "Glee
Club Singer," was clever enough
to somewhat disguise the features
of the member of the Hopkins Glee
Club that he had in mind while
making the drawing. There is quite
a difference of opinion as to which
member of the Club the drawing
most resembles. A free copy of
the drawing, suitable for framing,
will be presented to the reader of
THE NEWS-LETTER making the most
plausible suggestion as to the member of the Club the drawing is
really intended to represent.
Contestants' Note—Observe carefully the features of the accompaning reproduction of the "Glee Club
Singer" in the adjoining column,
and after thinking over the matter
write out the name of the original
of the drawing and give the reasons for your choice in not more
than twenty-five words. Mail the
same to the Contest Editor of THE
NEWS-LETTER, who has been placed
in charge of the matter by the manager of the Musical Clubs.
